, Waivers: • Where a threat may be posed to national security, the life or physical safety of any individual may be endangered, or a law enforcement action may be compromised; • Where an agency’s need for goods and services is of such unusual compelling urgency that the government would be seriously injured unless payment is made by a method other than electronic funds transfer; or, where there is only one source for goods or services and the government would be seriously injured unless payment is made a method other than electronic funds transfer. ) The IRS has two separate business units that require funds to support Revenue Code law enforcement operations: • CI serves as the law enforcement arm of the IRS and performs undercover operations in support of its mission. CI establishes investi- gative imprest funds to provide special agents with funding for covert operations. • SB/SE conducts liquidation auctions as part of its responsibilities the Property Appraisal and Liquidation (PAL) program. SB/SE does have the capability to conduct electronic sales transactions at most auction locations and must provide the opportunity to support cash sales as provided in

The IRS has two separate business units that require funds to support Internal Revenue Code law enforcement operations:

• CI serves as the law enforcement arm of the IRS and performs various undercover operations in support of its mission. CI establishes investi- gative imprest funds to provide special agents with funding for ongoing covert operations. • SB/SE conducts liquidation auctions as part of its responsibilities under the Property Appraisal and Liquidation (PAL) program. SB/SE does not have the capability to conduct electronic sales transactions at most auction locations and must provide the opportunity to support cash sales as provided in
CFR

),Payment of Bid Price, This subsection states, in part: ″All payments for property sold under this section shall be made by cash or by certiﬁed, cashier’s or treasur- er’s check drawn on any bank or trust company incorporated under the laws of the United States or under the laws of any State….. This neces- sitates that cash be made available to support the program.

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Accountable officer - A certifying officer, disbursing officer, collecting official, cashier and any other officer or employee who is responsible or has custody of public funds. b. Cashier - A U.S. government employee who is responsible for issuing and reconciling requested funds from an imprest fund. c. Class A cashier - A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation and has not been autho- rized to advance an imprest fund to another cashier, except the The Class A cashier is personally accountable to the head of the agency or designee for the entire amount of the advance received. d. Class B cashier - A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation and is authorized to advance an imprest fund to his or her own alternate and to a The Class B cashier is personally accountable to the head of the agency or designee for the entire amount of the advance received. e. Class D cashier - A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation solely for change-making purposes. They may advance funds to sub-cashiers for purposes only upon authorization by the head of the federal agency Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
W

a. Maintaining the safety and security of funds used to ensure that enough money is available to provide change to successful bidders at cash sales. b. Maintaining an accurate record of all transactions and ensuring the fund balance is maintained and returned to the PAL cashier within ﬁve business days after the conclusion of the liquidation auction. c. Accepting personal accountability and responsibility for the custody of the change fund, including responsibility for all shortages. Sub
cashiers may be directed to restore losses for which they are liable.
(11-24-2020) Program Management and Review
e. Audits and Independent reviews The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Accountable officer
A certifying officer, disbursing officer, collecting official, cashier and any other officer or employee who is responsible for or has custody of public funds. b. Cashier
A U.S. government employee who is responsible for issuing and reconciling requested funds from an imprest fund. c. Class A cashier
A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation and has not been autho

rized to advance an imprest fund to another cashier, except the alternate. The Class A cashier is personally accountable to the head of the federal agency or designee for the entire amount of the advance received. d. Class B cashier
A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation and is authorized to advance an imprest fund to his or her own alternate and to a sub
cashier. The Class B cashier is personally accountable to the head of the federal agency or designee for the entire amount of the advance received. e. Class D cashier
A cashier, officer, or employee who receives an advance from a federal agency appropriation solely for change
making purposes. They may advance funds to sub
cashiers for change
making purposes only upon authorization by the head of the federal agency from
countable to the head of the federal agency for the entire amount of advance. f. Sub
cashier

A permanent officer or employee who has been in writing by the head of a federal department designee to receive an imprest fund from a Class B or D cashier, and who is under the sion of the head of the same business unit as the cashier from whom advance is received and is accountable to such cashier for the funds received. The provisions for payment limitations and safekeeping that apply to cashiers also apply to sub
cashiers. g. Certifying officer
An individual who is personally accountable and sponsible for the accuracy and legality of payments made from federal government funds. h. Checking account signature cards
Cards signed by individuals for opening a checking account at a ﬁnancial institution. i. CI imprest fund computer program
A computer software program used by cashiers to input and track investigative imprest fund transac
tions. j. Churning
The act of using income generated from an undercover operation to offset the necessary and reasonable expenses of operations. k. Disbursing officer
An employee of the federal government, a disbursing officer, or non
Treasury disbursing officer, authorized to ﬁnancial transactions (deposit collections, disburse checks, and transfer funds between agencies). l. Imprest fund
Funds advanced to a duly authorized cashier for a purpose which is charged against a government appropriation account. m. Internal orders
Data elements in the Integrated Financial System identifying project costs at the lowest level of budget detail issued by corporate budget. n. Investigative expenditures
Conﬁdential and non
conﬁdential incurred by special agents in connection with an undercover program. The following acronyms apply to this program: Acronym Description
Investigative expenditures - Conﬁdential and non-conﬁdential expenses incurred by special agents in connection with an undercover program.

) The IRS uses imprest funds to support: a. CI with IRS law enforcement and investigative activities, and Funds b. SB/SE property appraisal and liquidation (PAL) specialists conducting auctions of seized assets. (
) CI establishes an investigative imprest fund when there is no other means of providing funds essential for the enforcement of laws and regula- tions. (
) CI maintains investigative imprest funds in checking accounts at federally insured banks or credit unions under the account name “CI Imprest Fund”. (

) CI is authorized to certify imprest fund disbursements for the enforcement laws and regulations for investigating and enforcing the Internal Revenue Code. All investigative imprest fund disbursements are recorded and within the CI Imprest Fund computer program. (

) All CI investigative imprest fund cashiers balance their ﬁnancial institution account statements and their disbursements, submitting copies to the Payable and Financial Operations office, via the Miscellaneous Programs monthly. (

) The international operations authorizations are maintained using the same vestigative authorization procedures as CI domestic operations. Exceptions these procedures are discussed in this subsection. (
) CI manages international investigative imprest operations through a imprest fund office located in Washington, DC. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Relief will be granted only in cases where the loss occurred through no fault the cashier. (

) Relief will not be granted in cases where the loss has occurred because of negligence on the part of the cashier. The CI director, Special Investigative Techniques or CI director/assistant director, Finance determines whether the cashier has been negligent in the performance of imprest fund duties. As a guideline for this determination, negligence may be indicated by the of one or more of the following factors : a. Frequent errors in transactions, record keeping, or reports b. Embezzlement or misappropriation of imprest funds c. Failure to maintain records and/or to submit reports d. Unprotected imprest funds, particularly if theft is involved e. Unauthorized or improperly documented transactions f. Unexplained disappearance or shortage of imprest funds (

) Relief may not be granted for circumstances involving illegal, improper, or incorrect payments, both in nature and amount, including those resulting fraud, forgery, alterations of vouchers, and other improper practices. (
